words.name: Coalition

words.def: Given a preference ν on the outcome space, an outcome a is a condorcet winner if all non-dummy players prefer a to all other outcomes.
words.name: Condorcet winner

words.def:
Given a preference ν on the outcome space, we say that an outcome a is dominated by outcome b (hence, b is the dominant strategy) if it is preferred by all players. If, in addition, some player strictly prefers b over a, then we say that a is strictly dominated. Formally:

  
    
      
        ∀

An outcome a is (strictly) dominated if it is (strictly) dominated by some other outcome.
An outcome a is dominated for a coalition S if all players in S prefer some other outcome to a. See also Condorcet winner.
words.name: Dominated outcome

A strategy σ is (strictly) dominated if it is (strictly) dominated by some other strategy.
words.name: Dominated strategy

words.def: A player i is a dummy if he has no effect on the outcome of the game. I.e. if the outcome of the game is insensitive to player i's strategy.
words.name: Dummy

words.def: A coalition (or a single player) S is effective for a if it can force a to be the outcome of the game. S is α-effective if the members of S have strategies s.t. no matter what the complement of S does, the outcome will be a.
words.name: Effectiveness

words.def: is a game with finitely many players, each of which has a finite set of strategies.
words.name: Finite game

words.def: refers to the coalition containing all players. In cooperative games it is often assumed that the grand coalition forms and the purpose of the game is to find stable imputations.
words.name: Grand coalition

words.def:
for player i is a probability distribution P on 
  
    
      
        Σ
        
           
          
            i
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \Sigma \ ^{i}}
  
. It is understood that player i chooses a strategy randomly according to P.
words.name: Mixed strategy

words.def: Same as Pure Nash Equilibrium, defined on the space of mixed strategies. Every finite game has Mixed Nash Equilibria.
words.name: Mixed Nash Equilibrium

words.def: An outcome a of game form π is (strongly) pareto efficient if it is undominated under all preference profiles.
words.name: Pareto efficiency

words.def:

. This is the ordinal approach at describing the outcome of the game. The preference describes how 'pleased' the players are with the possible outcomes of the game. See allocation of goods.
words.name: Preference profile

words.name: Pure Nash Equilibrium

words.def: A player i has a Say if he is not a Dummy, i.e. if there is some tuple of complement strategies s.t. π (σ_i) is not a constant function.
words.name: Say

words.def: A value of a game is a rationally expected outcome. There are more than a few definitions of value, describing different methods of obtaining a solution to the game.
words.name: Value

words.def: A veto denotes the ability (or right) of some player to prevent a specific alternative from being the outcome of the game. A player who has that ability is called a veto player.
words.name: Veto

words.def: is a game that has pure nash equilibria some of which are pareto efficient.
words.name: Weakly acceptable game

w.l.g. we can assume that constant to be zero. In a zero sum game, one player's gain is another player's loss. Most classical board games (e.g. chess, checkers) are zero sum.
words.name: Zero sum game
